text: Several answers already gave you the crux of your problem, but I want to make a plug for my favorite way to get logical line continuation in Python, when feasible:

code:
print "%2d. %8.2f %8.2f %8.2f" % (         # no mistake here
            i, lyhennys, korkoera, kuukausiera)

text: i.e., instead of using extra parentheses as some answers advise, you can take advantage of any parenthesis you already naturally happen to have -- that will tell Python that you need logical line continuation, too;-)
You can't have anything, even whitespace, after the line continuation character.
Either delete the whitespace, or wrap the entire line in a pair of parentheses.
Python implicitly joins lines between parentheses, curly braces, and square brackets:

childList.text: Python implicitly joins lines between parentheses, curly braces, and square brackets

text: Try modifying these lines:

code:
print "%2d. %8.2f %8.2f %8.2f" % \         # mistake probably here
            (i, lyhennys, korkoera, kuukausiera)

text: to this line:
Also, note that a line ending with a backslash cannot carry a comment.
So your #mistake probably here comment is likely causing the problem.
Try rewriting this:

code:
print "%2d. %8.2f %8.2f %8.2f" % \         # mistake probably here
            (i, lyhennys, korkoera, kuukausiera)

text: To this:
\ should work too, but IMO it's less readable.
Replace:
By:
General remark: always use English for identifiers
In general, I find I don't use line continuation in Python.
You can make it cleaner with parentheses and so on.
"\" means "this line continue to the next line" and it can't have any character after it.
There probably is a space right after.
Two solution :
Ensure there is not spaces after;
Rewrite the statement on one line :
You can even use parenthesis to make it fit on several lines :
